person.death: 1710Eggert's father acquires a manuscript sometime after 1661. Eggert gets it after his father and passes it on to one Ari Þorkelsson who again hands it over to Árni Magnússon in 1697. person.occupation: Pope A notable theologian who was also an administrative, social, liturgical, and moral reformer. Drawing upon St. Augustine's City of God for his views, Gregory formulated ideas of a Christian society that became formalized in the Middle Ages. Among his accomplishments were a reform of the mass from which came the Gregorian chant. Since the 8th century he has been regarded as a doctor (teacher) of the church.

residence.note: Jón Egilsson is of Norwegian origin and probably both born and raised there. He, however, spent most of his working life in Iceland. Documents written by Jón are therefore in a language mixture of Icelandic and Norwegian.

occupation.note: Is refered to as "Grandfather Jón" ("Jón afi") in AM 64 8vo.

bibl.note: One Jón Halldórsson (Joen Haldorsøn) is mentioned in 1658 as a previous owner of the Icelandic Graduale of 1649 and said to live in Hvaleyri in Hafnarfjörður. This one is probably the same as the one in Innri-Njarðvík, his father having lived on Hvaleyri in Hafnarfjörður.
Writes the manuscript AM 136 b 8vo in 1658.
Writes his name on page 1r in AM 434 c 12mo in 1650. The reading of the name of the farm, Staðarfell, is ambigious.
Jón Jónsson finished writing his manuscript, AM 600 b 4to, on the 18th of June 1677
Jón Jónsson is connected with the manuscript AM 379 4to in the episcopal seat Hólar in 1675.
Is reported by Árni Magnússon to have owned parts of AM 75 c fol.
AM 232 fol (54v), AM 589 f 4to. Possibly two by the same name. One Jón Ketilsson is mentioned in a document in 1481, Diplomatarium Islandicum VI, p. 381.
AM 66 b 4to. Is mentioned in a document written at Heynes in 1637.
AM 25 8vo. Possibly the same as JonMag003.
AM 1058 4to (letter no. 56). Jón writes a letter to Ragnheiður Pálsdóttir (RagPal01) in 1617.

person.note: Brother of Peter Salan and correspondent of English antiquarian George Hickes. Fl. late 17th c.

bibl.note: AM 433 a 12mo is a property of Jón Sigfússon in 1657.
Is mentioned in documents (AM 703 IV 4to) concerning properties in Snæfellsnessýsla in 1638-1640. Possibly the same as JonSig06

AM 662 b 4to. Jón Sigurðsson is said to have lived at "Melo Rosso" which probably is a latinized form for "Rauðimelur" but he is not mentioned as living at either one of the two farms with that name in the census from 1703 (unless he is, at that time, a servant of 18 years, see Manntal 1703, p. 87).

AM 1058 4to #104. Jón Snorrason wrote a letter in Þorlákshöfn 27 March 1791 to Steindór Finsson. Jón Snorrason is possibly the same as Jón Snorrason the ship-builder (1764-1846, see Íslenzkar æviskrár V, pp. 410-411). Steindór Finnsson is probably the one who was sýslumaður in Árnessýsla 1772-1813 (1743-1819, see Íslenzkar æviskrár IV, p. 345).

occupation.note: Rask 94 is written by Jón S...son in 1735. The scribe only gives a way his name (Jón) and his initials (I.S.S.). He was probably a resident in Eyjafjarðarsýsla as fragments of letters from that part of Iceland make up the binding.

bibl.note: AM 243 e fol. NB JonSte001 and JonSte003.
AM 667 4to VIII, p. 2v. Nota bene JonSte001 and Jon Ste002.
AM 539 4to, AM 554 h a 4to, AM 630 4to, AM 779 c 4to.
AM 63 4to, AM 38 8vo, [Printed books: sacri, doctrinales #216]. Probably more than one man by the name Jón Þorsteinsson.
Marginalia concerning Jón Þorsteinsson places him at Melgraseyri in 1601 or 1661.
AM 640 4to. Inventarium from Ærlækur, probably from 1504, when Jón Þorsteinsson took office there.
AM 692 c 4to. A letter by Páll Björnsson (1621-1706) dated 24 November 1671 is addressed to Jón Úlfsson.

person.death: alive in the second half of 18th c.

person.occupation: Priest Rector Magnús Markússon also played a significant role as a scribe in Árni Magnússons apographical project (the copying of old documents).

bibl.note: In AM 625 4to, p. 11r., is written "magnus palls ritadi mik", "palls" probably being short for Pálsson.

AM 81 8vo. On a note it is stated that the manuscript comes from one "Magnus Sigurdsen i Vig". Kålunds Katalog sees "Vig" as a typo for "Vík" but Magnús Sigurðsson has not been found at any of the farms with that name in the census from 1703. On the farm Vigur in Ísafjarðarsýsla, however, there lives, according to the 1703 census, one Sigurður Magnússon, possibly a son of Magnús (which probably is dead at that time). The name "Vig" is, then, not a typo for "Vík" but an irregular form of "Vigur" (in dativus singularis).

occupation.note: Married to Þorgeir Jónsson (ThorJon003)

person.note: Collector of manuscripts. In 1710 the Wolfenbüttel library bought the main part of his manuscript collection.

bibl.note: AM 612 e 4to. Árni Magnússon got this manuscript from one Oddur Gíslason "undir Eyjafjöllum" (i.e. in the area south of Eyjafjöll). In 1703 this Oddur is the only one with that name in the vicinity.
AM 84 8vo. A previous owner, Árni Ólafsson (ArnOla001), probably got the manuscript from Oddur between 1691 and 1709. In the census of 1703 the farm Fagrahlíð is deserted.
AM 410 fol. Writer of a letter to Hjalti Þorsteinsson (HjaThor001).
AM 39 fol. Árni Magnússon is in doubt whether parts of this manuscript belonged to the priest Oddur (which patronymic he omits) or one Jón Guðmundsson (JonGud004).
AM 433 d 12mo. Ólafur Andrésson is also mentioned in Rask 39 (13), but it is doubtful whether it's one and the same.
Steph. 54. It is uncertain whether one Jón Ólafsson, who is noted to have owned the manuscript in 1713, and the one cited here are one and the same but it is probable.
AM 66 a 8vo. OlaJon004 and OlaJon005 could be one and the same.
AM 63 8vo. OlaJon004 and OlaJon005 could be one and the same.

AM 64 8vo. Uncertain. See SigSig003 (older brother of Sigurður Sigurðsson).
AM 103 8vo. Possibly the same man as SigSig005.
Accessoria 1. Possibly the same as SigSig005.
AM 652 4to. Possibly daughter of Sigmundur Guðmundsson (SigGud001).
In AM 325 X 4to the name Snæbjörn Stefánsson is written in a marginal note with a scribal hand from 17th century. It is not unlikely that this is the same man as described under SnaeSte001.
At least two men by that name are known from the 17th century, see bibliography.

person.occupation: Professor of comparative philology and Old Norse
person.note: Pioneered in the collection and study of Norwegian folk songs, gathered a massive quantity of ancient Norwegian inscriptions, and prepared what is considered to be one of the most outstanding critical editions of the Poetic Edda, the 13th-century Icelandic collection of heroic and mythological poetry. His edition of Old Norse folk songs appeared in 1858.

person.occupation: Professor and judge of the Higher Court

bibl.note: Worked on the edition of Fornmanna sögur. The same man as Þorsteinn Helgason (1806-39)?

note.p: Samkvæmt skráningargögnum Bessastaðaskóla fæddist Þórður 9. janúar 1800

person.birth: 1379/80 Kempen, near Düsseldorf The Rhineland (now in Germany)
person.death: 8 August 1471 Agnietenberg, near Zwolle Bishopric of Utrecht (now in the Netherlands)

person.birth: 23 April 1588 Lund Skåne Denmark, now Sweden
23. april 1588 Lund Skåne Danmark, nu Sverige

person.persName: Brahe, Tyge Ottesen Tyge Ottesen Brahe
person.birth: 14 December 1546 Knudstrup Skåne Denmark, now Sweden
25 March 1819 Stegaard (á Steig) near Sandavágur Vágar Faroe Islands

bibl.ref: Fiona MacCarthy, ‘Morris, William (1834–1896)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Oct 2009 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/19322, accessed 10 Sept 2013]

bibl.note: Evangelized the Goths, reputedly created the Gothic alphabet, and wrote the earliest translation of the Bible into Gothic.
